title: Hurricane Vince
original:
Hurricane Vince was an unusual tropical cyclone that developed in the northeastern Atlantic basin. Forming in October during the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season, it strengthened over waters thought to be too cold for tropical development. Vince was the twentieth named storm and twelfth hurricane of the extremely active season.
Vince developed from an extratropical system on 8 October, becoming a subtropical storm southeast of the Azores. The United States National Hurricane Center (NHC) did not officially name the storm until the next day, shortly before Vince became a hurricane. The storm weakened at sea and made an extremely rare landfall on the Iberian Peninsula as a tropical depression on 11 October. Vince was one of only three tropical or subtropical cyclones to do so, alongside the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha of 2020. It dissipated over Spain, bringing much-needed rain to the region, and its remnants passed into the Mediterranean Sea.
simplified:
Hurricane Vince was a rare storm that formed in the northeast Atlantic Ocean. It happened in October 2005, during a very busy hurricane season. What made Vince unusual was that it grew strong in waters that were thought to be too cold for hurricanes to form.

Vince started as a different kind of storm on October 8, then became a subtropical storm near the Azores islands. The next day, weather experts officially named it and soon after, it became a full hurricane.

The storm got weaker as it moved over the ocean. On October 11, it hit land in Spain and Portugal as a weak tropical storm. This almost never happens in that area. Only two other similar storms have ever hit there, one in 1842 and another in 2020.

After reaching land, Vince broke up over Spain. It brought some much-needed rain to the area before its leftovers moved into the Mediterranean Sea.

simplicity_issues.original_span: made an extremely rare landfall on the Iberian Peninsula as a tropical depression on 11 October
simplicity_issues.simplified_span: hit land in Spain and Portugal as a weak tropical storm
simplicity_issues.explanation: The original text specifies that Vince made landfall as a tropical depression, not a weak tropical storm. This distinction is important as it indicates the storm's intensity at landfall.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Replace 'as a weak tropical storm' with 'as a tropical depression'.

simplicity_issues.original_span: Vince was one of only three tropical or subtropical cyclones to do so, alongside the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha of 2020.
simplicity_issues.simplified_span: Only two other similar storms have ever hit there, one in 1842 and another in 2020.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The simplified text omits the specific names of the other two storms, which are important for historical context and specificity.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Include the names of the other storms: 'Only two other similar storms have ever hit there, the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha of 2020.'

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: during a very busy hurricane season
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase 'very busy hurricane season' is imprecise and could be more specific.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: during the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season, which was particularly active

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: What made Vince unusual was that it grew strong in waters that were thought to be too cold for hurricanes to form.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The sentence is long and contains multiple clauses, which can make it harder to follow.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Vince was unusual because it strengthened in waters considered too cold for hurricane formation.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: Vince started as a different kind of storm on October 8, then became a subtropical storm near the Azores islands.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase 'a different kind of storm' is vague and does not specify what type of storm it was.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Vince started as an extratropical cyclone on October 8, then became a subtropical storm near the Azores islands.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: weather experts officially named it and soon after, it became a full hurricane.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The transition between naming the storm and it becoming a hurricane is abrupt.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: weather experts officially named it. Soon after, it intensified into a full hurricane.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: This almost never happens in that area.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The sentence lacks specificity and could be more informative about the rarity of such events.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Such storms rarely occur in that area.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: Only two other similar storms have ever hit there, one in 1842 and another in 2020.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The sentence could be clearer by specifying what 'there' refers to.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Only two other similar storms have ever hit the Iberian Peninsula, one in 1842 and another in 2020.

title: Hurricane Vince
original:
Hurricane Vince was an unusual tropical cyclone that developed in the northeastern Atlantic basin. Forming in October during the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season, it strengthened over waters thought to be too cold for tropical development. Vince was the twentieth named storm and twelfth hurricane of the extremely active season.
Vince developed from an extratropical system on 8 October, becoming a subtropical storm southeast of the Azores. The United States National Hurricane Center (NHC) did not officially name the storm until the next day, shortly before Vince became a hurricane. The storm weakened at sea and made an extremely rare landfall on the Iberian Peninsula as a tropical depression on 11 October. Vince was one of only three tropical or subtropical cyclones to do so, alongside the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha of 2020. It dissipated over Spain, bringing much-needed rain to the region, and its remnants passed into the Mediterranean Sea.
simplified:
Hurricane Vince was a strange tropical storm that formed in the northeastern Atlantic Ocean. It appeared in October during the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season, and it got stronger over water that was thought to be too cold for tropical storms to form. Vince was the twentieth storm to be named and the twelfth hurricane in this very active season.

Vince started from a non-tropical weather system on October 8, turning into a subtropical storm southeast of the Azores islands. The United States National Hurricane Center (NHC) didn't officially give it a name until the next day, just before Vince became a hurricane. The storm got weaker while still at sea and made a very rare landfall on the Iberian Peninsula as a tropical depression on October 11. Vince was one of only three storms like this to reach the Iberian Peninsula, along with the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha in 2020. It faded away over Spain, but it brought much-needed rain to the area, and what's left of it moved into the Mediterranean Sea.

simplicity_issues.original_span: Vince developed from an extratropical system on 8 October, becoming a subtropical storm southeast of the Azores.
simplicity_issues.simplified_span: Vince started from a non-tropical weather system on October 8, turning into a subtropical storm southeast of the Azores islands.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The term 'extratropical system' is more specific than 'non-tropical weather system.' The original specifies the type of non-tropical system, which is important for understanding the storm's development.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Replace 'non-tropical weather system' with 'extratropical system' to maintain the specificity of the original text.

simplicity_issues.original_span: Vince was one of only three tropical or subtropical cyclones to do so, alongside the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha of 2020.
simplicity_issues.simplified_span: Vince was one of only three storms like this to reach the Iberian Peninsula, along with the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha in 2020.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The simplified text uses 'storms like this' which is less precise than 'tropical or subtropical cyclones.' The original specifies the types of storms, which is important for understanding the rarity of the event.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Replace 'storms like this' with 'tropical or subtropical cyclones' to maintain the specificity of the original text.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: a strange tropical storm
simplicity_issues.explanation: The word 'strange' is vague and does not provide specific information about why the storm is considered unusual.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: an unusual tropical storm

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: that was thought to be too cold for tropical storms to form
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase is somewhat awkward and could be simplified for clarity.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: considered too cold for tropical storms

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: Vince was one of only three storms like this to reach the Iberian Peninsula, along with the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha in 2020.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The sentence contains multiple ideas and could be split for clarity.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Vince was one of only three storms to reach the Iberian Peninsula. The others were the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha in 2020.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: what's left of it moved into the Mediterranean Sea
simplicity_issues.explanation: The contraction 'what's' is informal and inconsistent with the rest of the text's tone.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: its remnants moved into the Mediterranean Sea

title: Hurricane Vince
original:
Hurricane Vince was an unusual tropical cyclone that developed in the northeastern Atlantic basin. Forming in October during the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season, it strengthened over waters thought to be too cold for tropical development. Vince was the twentieth named storm and twelfth hurricane of the extremely active season.
Vince developed from an extratropical system on 8 October, becoming a subtropical storm southeast of the Azores. The United States National Hurricane Center (NHC) did not officially name the storm until the next day, shortly before Vince became a hurricane. The storm weakened at sea and made an extremely rare landfall on the Iberian Peninsula as a tropical depression on 11 October. Vince was one of only three tropical or subtropical cyclones to do so, alongside the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha of 2020. It dissipated over Spain, bringing much-needed rain to the region, and its remnants passed into the Mediterranean Sea.
simplified:
Hurricane Vince was a strange storm that happened in the north-east part of the Atlantic Ocean during the 2005 hurricane season. It grew stronger than expected, even though the ocean water was colder than usual for a tropical storm to form. Vince was the 20th storm and the 12th hurricane of a very busy season.

The storm started as a non-tropical system on October 8th and then turned into a subtropical storm south of the Azores islands. The U.S. National Hurricane Center didn’t give it a name until the following day, just before it became a hurricane.  It got weaker as it traveled across the ocean and then, very rarely, it hit land in Portugal on October 11th as a weak tropical depression.  Only three other tropical or subtropical storms have ever done this before – a hurricane in 1842 and a subtropical storm in 2020.  The storm disappeared over Spain, bringing rain to the area, and its pieces then moved into the Mediterranean Sea.

simplicity_issues.original_span: Vince was one of only three tropical or subtropical cyclones to do so, alongside the 1842 Spanish hurricane and Subtropical Storm Alpha of 2020.
simplicity_issues.simplified_span: Only three other tropical or subtropical storms have ever done this before – a hurricane in 1842 and a subtropical storm in 2020.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The simplified text incorrectly states that three other storms have made landfall on the Iberian Peninsula, implying a total of four, including Vince. The original text clarifies that Vince is one of the three, not in addition to three others.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Revise to: 'Vince was one of only three tropical or subtropical storms to hit land in this area, along with a hurricane in 1842 and a subtropical storm in 2020.'

simplicity_issues.original_span: made an extremely rare landfall on the Iberian Peninsula as a tropical depression on 11 October.
simplicity_issues.simplified_span: it hit land in Portugal on October 11th as a weak tropical depression.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The simplified text specifies Portugal, whereas the original text refers to the Iberian Peninsula, which includes both Portugal and Spain. This changes the geographical scope of the event.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Revise to: 'it hit land on the Iberian Peninsula on October 11th as a weak tropical depression.'

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: a strange storm
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase 'a strange storm' is imprecise and does not provide specific information about what makes the storm strange.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: an unusual storm

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: north-east part of the Atlantic Ocean
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase 'north-east part of the Atlantic Ocean' could be simplified for clarity.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: northeastern Atlantic Ocean

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: even though the ocean water was colder than usual for a tropical storm to form
simplicity_issues.explanation: This phrase is long and contains multiple clauses, which can make it harder to follow.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: despite colder-than-usual ocean water for tropical storm formation

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: The storm started as a non-tropical system on October 8th and then turned into a subtropical storm south of the Azores islands.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The sentence contains multiple ideas that could be separated for clarity.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: The storm started as a non-tropical system on October 8th. It then turned into a subtropical storm south of the Azores islands.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: very rarely
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase 'very rarely' is vague and does not provide specific information.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: uncommonly

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: Only three other tropical or subtropical storms have ever done this before – a hurricane in 1842 and a subtropical storm in 2020.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The sentence lacks clarity because it does not specify what 'this' refers to.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Only three other tropical or subtropical storms have ever hit Portugal before – a hurricane in 1842 and a subtropical storm in 2020.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: bringing rain to the area, and its pieces then moved into the Mediterranean Sea.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase 'its pieces then moved into the Mediterranean Sea' is awkward and unclear.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: bringing rain to the area, and remnants of the storm moved into the Mediterranean Sea.
